ORDER granting 246 Motion for Change of Plea as to Magaly Hernandez-Cruz (11) and adopting 260 Report and Recommendations on Plea of Guilty as to Magaly Hernandez- Cruz (11). The Court has evaluated the Magistrate Judge's Report and Recommendation to accept the guilty plea as it was made in accordance with the safeguards provided by Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 11. "[OJur first consideration is whether the plea was knowing, voluntary and intelligent as understood in terms of Rule 11." United States v. Isom, 85 F.3d 831, 835-837 (1st Cir. 1996). In order to ascertain whether Defendant made a knowing, voluntary, and intelligent plea, the First Circuit has "identified three 'core concerns of Rule 11: 1) absence of coercion; 2) the defendant's understanding of the charges; and 3) the defendant's knowledge of the consequences of the guilty plea." Isom,

F.3d at 835 (citing United States v. Gray, 63 F.3d 57, 60 (1st Cir.1995)); see also United States v. Cotal Crespo, 47 F.3d 1, 4 (1st Cir.1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 827 (1995). The Court, in examining the three core concerns, must "review the totality of the circumstances surrounding the Rule 11 hearing, rather than apply a 'talismatic test."" Isom, 85 F.3d at 835 (citing Cotal, 47 F.3d at 4-5). Having examined the Report and Recommendation of the Magistrate Judge, the Court finds that Defendant's plea was entered knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 11/17/2016. (MF) (Entered: 11/17/2016)

ORDER granting 255 Motion for Change of Plea as to Carlos Rivera-Rivera (17) and adopting 307 Report and Recommendations on Plea of Guilty as to Carlos Rivera-Rivera (17). The Court has evaluated the Magistrate Judge's Report and Recommendation to accept the guilty plea as it was made in accordance with the safeguards provided by Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 11. "[OJur first consideration is whether the plea was knowing, voluntary and intelligent as understood in terms of Rule 11." United States v. Isom, 85 F.3d 831, 835-837 (1st Cir. 1996). In order to ascertain whether Defendant made a knowing, voluntary, and intelligent plea, the First Circuit has "identified three 'core concerns of Rule 11: 1) absence of coercion; 2) the defendant's understanding of the charges; and 3) the defendant's knowledge of the consequences of the guilty plea." Isom, 85 F.3d at 835 (citing United States v. Gray, 63 F.3d 57, 60 (1st Cir.1995)); see also United States v. Cotal Crespo, 47 F.3d 1, 4 (ist Cir.1995), cert. denied, 516 U.S. 827 (1995). The Court, in examining the three core concerns, must "review the totality of the circumstances surrounding the Rule 11 hearing, rather than apply a 'talismatic test." Isom, 85 F.3d at 835 (citing Cotal, 47 F.3d at 4-5). Having examined the Report and Recommendation of the Magistrate Judge, the Court finds that Defendant's plea was entered knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently. Signed by Judge Daniel R. Dominguez on 1/13/2017. (MF) (Entered: 01/13/2017)

Morales-Senquiz (23). The Court has evaluated each Report and Recommendation to accept each guilty plea as they were made in accordance with the safeguards provided by Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 11. "[OJur first consideration is whether the plea was knowing, voluntary and intelligent as understood in terms of Rule 11." United States v. Isom, 85 F.3d 831, 835-837 (1st Cir. 1996). In order to ascertain whether Defendants made a knowing, voluntary, and intelligent plea, the First Circuit has "identified three 'core concerns of Rule 11: 1) absence of coercion; 2) the defendant's understanding of the charges; and 3) the defendant's knowledge of the consequences of the guilty plea." Isom, 85 F.3d at 835 (citing United States v. Gray, 63 F.3d 57, 60 (1st Cir.1995)); see also United States v. Cotal Crespo, 47 F.3d 1, 4 (1st Cir.1995), cert.  denied, 516 U.S. 827 (1995). The Court, in examining the three core concerns, must "review the totality of the circumstances surrounding the Rule 11 hearing, rather than apply a 'talismatic test.'" Isom, 85 F.3d at 835 (citing Cotal, 47 F.3d at 4-5). Having examined each Report and Recommendation, the Court finds that Defendant's plea was entered knowingly, voluntarily, and intelligently.
